channel.title: Freakonomics Radio
channel.description: Discover the hidden side of everything with Stephen J. Dubner, co-author of the Freakonomics books. Each week, Freakonomics Radio tells you things you always thought you knew (but didn’t) and things you never thought you wanted to know (but do) — from the economics of sleep to how to become great at just about anything. Dubner speaks with Nobel laureates and provocateurs, intellectuals and entrepreneurs, and various other underachievers. The entire archive, going back to 2010, is available on the Stitcher podcast app and at freakonomics.com.
channel.itunes:summary: Discover the hidden side of everything with Stephen J. Dubner, co-author of the Freakonomics books. Each week, Freakonomics Radio tells you things you always thought you knew (but didn’t) and things you never thought you wanted to know (but do) — from the economics of sleep to how to become great at just about anything. Dubner speaks with Nobel laureates and provocateurs, intellectuals and entrepreneurs, and various other underachievers. The entire archive, going back to 2010, is available on the Stitcher podcast app and at freakonomics.com.
channel.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio + Stitcher

item.title: 447. How Much Do We Really Care About Children?
item.itunes:title: How Much Do We Really Care About Children?
item.description: They can’t vote or hire lobbyists. The policies we create to help them aren’t always so helpful. Consider the car seat: parents hate it, the safety data are unconvincing, and new evidence suggests an unintended consequence that is as anti-child as it gets.
item.content:encoded: They can’t vote or hire lobbyists. The policies we create to help them aren’t always so helpful. Consider the car seat: parents hate it, the safety data are unconvincing, and new evidence suggests an unintended consequence that is as anti-child as it gets.

item.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio + Stitcher

item.title: 446. “We Get All Our Great Stuff from Europe — Including Witch Hunting.”
item.itunes:title: “We Get All Our Great Stuff from Europe — Including Witch Hunting.”
item.description: We’ve collected some of our favorite moments from People I (Mostly) Admire, the latest show from the Freakonomics Radio Network. Host Steve Levitt seeks advice from scientists and inventors, memory wizards and basketball champions — even his fellow economists. He also asks about quitting, witch trials, and whether we need a Manhattan Project for climate change.

item.title: Trust Me (Ep. 266 Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Trust Me (Ep. 266 Rebroadcast)
item.description: Societies where people trust one another are healthier and wealthier. In the U.S. (and the U.K. and elsewhere), social trust has been falling for decades — in part because our populations are more diverse. What can we do to fix it?
item.content:encoded: Societies where people trust one another are healthier and wealthier. In the U.S. (and the U.K. and elsewhere), social trust has been falling for decades — in part because our populations are more diverse. What can we do to fix it?

item.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio + Stitcher

item.title: 445. Why Do We Seek Comfort in the Familiar?
item.itunes:title: Why Do We Seek Comfort in the Familiar?
item.description: In this episode of No Stupid Questions — a Freakonomics Radio Network show launched earlier this year — Stephen Dubner and Angela Duckworth debate why we watch, read, and eat familiar things during a crisis, and if it might in fact be better to try new things instead. Also: is a little knowledge truly as dangerous as they say?
item.content:encoded: In this episode of No Stupid Questions — a Freakonomics Radio Network show launched earlier this year — Stephen Dubner and Angela Duckworth debate why we watch, read, and eat familiar things during a crisis, and if it might in fact be better to try new things instead. Also: is a little knowledge truly as dangerous as they say?

Also: is a little knowledge truly as dangerous as they say?
item.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio + Stitcher

item.title: 444. How Do You Cure a Compassion Crisis?
item.itunes:title: How Do You Cure a Compassion Crisis?
item.description: Patients in the U.S. healthcare system often feel they’re treated with a lack of empathy. Doctors and nurses have tragically high levels of burnout. Could fixing the first problem solve the second? And does the rest of society need more compassion too?
item.content:encoded: Patients in the U.S. healthcare system often feel they’re treated with a lack of empathy. Doctors and nurses have tragically high levels of burnout. Could fixing the first problem solve the second? And does the rest of society need more compassion too?

item.title: 443. A Sneak Peek at Biden’s Top Economist
item.itunes:title: A Sneak Peek at Biden’s Top Economist
item.description: The incoming president argues that the economy and the environment are deeply connected. This is reflected in his choice for National Economic Council director — Brian Deese, a climate-policy wonk and veteran of the no-drama-Obama era. But don’t mistake Deese’s lack of drama for a lack of intensity.

But don’t mistake Deese’s lack of drama for a lack of intensity.

item.title: PLAYBACK (2015): Could the Next Brooklyn Be ... Las Vegas?!
item.itunes:title: PLAYBACK (2015): Could the Next Brooklyn Be ... Las Vegas?!
item.description: Tony Hsieh, the longtime C.E.O. of Zappos, was an iconoclast and a dreamer. Five years ago, we sat down with him around a desert campfire to talk about those dreams. Hsieh died recently from injuries sustained in a house fire; he was 46.

item.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio + Stitcher

item.title: 442. Is it Too Late for General Motors to Go Electric?
item.itunes:title: Is it Too Late for General Motors to Go Electric?
item.description: G.M. produces more than 20 times as many cars as Tesla, but Tesla is worth nearly 10 times as much. Mary Barra, the C.E.O. of G.M., is trying to fix that. We speak with her about the race toward an electrified (and autonomous) future, China and Trump, and what it’s like to be the “fifth-most powerful woman in the world.”
item.content:encoded: G.M. produces more than 20 times as many cars as Tesla, but Tesla is worth nearly 10 times as much. Mary Barra, the C.E.O. of G.M., is trying to fix that. item.title: 441. Does Advertising Actually Work? (Part 2: Digital)
item.itunes:title: Does Advertising Actually Work? (Part 2: Digital)
item.description: Google and Facebook are worth a combined $2 trillion, with the vast majority of their revenue coming from advertising. In our previous episode, we learned that TV advertising is much less effective than the industry says. Is digital any better? Some say yes, some say no — and some say we’re in a full-blown digital-ad bubble.

item.title: 440. Does Advertising Actually Work? (Part 1: TV)
item.itunes:title: Does Advertising Actually Work? (Part 1: TV)
item.description: Companies around the world spend more than half-a-trillion dollars each year on ads. The ad industry swears by its efficacy — but a massive new study tells a different story.
item.content:encoded: Companies around the world spend more than half-a-trillion dollars each year on ads. The ad industry swears by its efficacy — but a massive new study tells a different story.

item.title: 439. Please Get Your Noise Out of My Ears
item.itunes:title: Please Get Your Noise Out of My Ears
item.description: The modern world overwhelms us with sounds we didn’t ask for, like car alarms and cell-phone “halfalogues.” What does all this noise cost us in terms of productivity, health, and basic sanity?
item.content:encoded: The modern world overwhelms us with sounds we didn’t ask for, like car alarms and cell-phone “halfalogues.” What does all this noise cost us in terms of productivity, health, and basic sanity?

item.title: 438. How to Succeed by Being Authentic (Hint: Carefully)
item.itunes:title: How to Succeed by Being Authentic (Hint: Carefully)
item.description: John Mackey, the C.E.O. of Whole Foods, has learned the perils of speaking his mind. But he still says what he thinks about everything from “conscious leadership” to the behavioral roots of the obesity epidemic. He also argues for a style of capitalism and politics that at this moment seems like a fantasy. What does he know that we don’t?

item.title: Why the Left Had to Steal the Right’s Dark-Money Playbook
item.itunes:title: Why the Left Had to Steal the Right’s Dark-Money Playbook
item.description: The sociologist Sudhir Venkatesh spent years studying crack dealers, sex workers, and the offspring of billionaires. Then he wandered into an even stranger world: social media. He spent the past five years at Facebook and Twitter. Now that he’s back in the real world, he’s here to tell us how the digital universe really works. In this pilot episode of a new podcast, Venkatesh interviews the progressive political operative Tara McGowan about her digital successes with the Obama campaign, her noisy failure with the Iowa caucus app, and why the best way for Democrats to win more elections was to copy the Republicans.

item.title: 437. Many Businesses Thought They Were Insured for a Pandemic. They Weren’t.
item.itunes:title: Many Businesses Thought They Were Insured for a Pandemic. They Weren’t.
item.description: A fine reading of most policies for “business interruption” reveals that viral outbreaks aren’t covered. Some legislators are demanding that insurance firms pay up anyway. Is it time to rethink insurance entirely?
item.content:encoded: A fine reading of most policies for “business interruption” reveals that viral outbreaks aren’t covered. Some legislators are demanding that insurance firms pay up anyway. Is it time to rethink insurance entirely?

item.title: 436. Forget Everything You Know About Your Dog
item.itunes:title: Forget Everything You Know About Your Dog
item.description: As beloved and familiar as they are, we rarely stop to consider life from the dog’s point of view. That stops now. In this latest installment of the Freakonomics Radio Book Club, we discuss Inside of a Dog with the cognitive scientist (and dog devotee) Alexandra Horowitz.

item.title: 435. Why Are Cities (Still) So Expensive?
item.itunes:title: Why Are Cities (Still) So Expensive?
item.description: It isn’t just supply and demand. We look at the complicated history and skewed incentives that make “affordable housing” more punch line than reality in cities from New York and San Francisco to Flint, Michigan (!).
item.content:encoded: It isn’t just supply and demand. We look at the complicated history and skewed incentives that make “affordable housing” more punch line than reality in cities from New York and San Francisco to Flint, Michigan (!).

item.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio + Stitcher

item.title: 434. Is New York City Over?
item.itunes:title: Is New York City Over?
item.description: The pandemic has hit America's biggest city particularly hard. Amidst a deep fiscal hole, rising homicides, and a flight to the suburbs, some people think the city is heading back to the bad old 1970s. We look at the history — and the data — to see why that’s probably not the case.

We look at the history — and the data — to see why that’s probably not the case.

item.title: “Don’t Neglect the Thing That Makes You Weird” | People I (Mostly) Admire: Ken Jennings
item.itunes:title: “Don’t Neglect the Thing That Makes You Weird” | People I (Mostly) Admire: Ken Jennings
item.description: It was only in his late twenties that America’s favorite brainiac began to seriously embrace his love of trivia. Now he holds the “Greatest of All Time” title on Jeopardy! Steve Levitt digs into how he trained for the show, what it means to have a "geographic memory," and why we lie to our children.

item.title: 433. How Are Psychedelics and Other Party Drugs Changing Psychiatry?
item.itunes:title: How Are Psychedelics and Other Party Drugs Changing Psychiatry?
item.description: Three leading researchers from the Mount Sinai Health System discuss how ketamine, cannabis, and ecstasy are being used (or studied) to treat everything from severe depression to addiction to PTSD. We discuss the upsides, downsides, and regulatory puzzles.
item.content:encoded: Three leading researchers from the Mount Sinai Health System discuss how ketamine, cannabis, and ecstasy are being used (or studied) to treat everything from severe depression to addiction to PTSD. We discuss the upsides, downsides, and regulatory puzzles.

item.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio + Stitcher

item.title: 432. When Your Safety Becomes My Danger
item.itunes:title: When Your Safety Becomes My Danger
item.description: The families of U.S. troops killed and wounded in Afghanistan are suing several companies that did reconstruction there. Why? These companies, they say, paid the Taliban protection money, which gave them the funding — and opportunity — to attack U.S. soldiers instead. A look at the messy, complicated, and heart-breaking tradeoffs of conflict-zone economies.
item.content:encoded: The families of U.S. troops killed and wounded in Afghanistan are suing several companies that did reconstruction there. Why? A look at the messy, complicated, and heart-breaking tradeoffs of conflict-zone economies.

item.title: “One Does Not Know Where an Insight Will Come From” | People I (Mostly) Admire: Kerwin Charles
item.itunes:title: “One Does Not Know Where an Insight Will Come From” | People I (Mostly) Admire: Kerwin Charles
item.description: The dean of Yale’s School of Management grew up in a small village in Guyana. During his unlikely journey, he has researched video-gaming habits, communicable disease, and why so many African-Americans haven’t had the kind of success he’s had. Steve Levitt talks to Charles about his parents’ encouragement, his love of Sports Illustrated, and how he talks to his American-born kids about the complicated history of Blackness in America.

item.title: Does Anyone Really Know What Socialism Is? (Ep. 408 Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Does Anyone Really Know What Socialism Is? (Ep. 408 Rebroadcast)
item.description: Trump says it would destroy us. Biden needs the voters who support it (especially the Bernie voters). The majority of millennials would like it to replace capitalism. But what is “it”? We bring in the economists to sort things out and tell us what the U.S. can learn from the good (and bad) experiences of other (supposedly) socialist countries.

item.title: What if Your Company Had No Rules?
item.itunes:title: What if Your Company Had No Rules?
item.description: Netflix co-founder Reed Hastings came to believe that corporate rules can kill creativity and innovation. In this latest edition of the Freakonomics Radio Book Club, guest host Maria Konnikova talks to Hastings about his new book, No Rules Rules, and why for some companies the greatest risk is taking no risks at all.

item.title: 431. Why Can’t Schools Get What the N.F.L. Has?
item.itunes:title: Why Can’t Schools Get What the N.F.L. Has?
item.description: Thanks to daily Covid testing and regimented protocols, the new football season is underway. Meanwhile, most teachers, students, and parents are essentially waiting for the storm to pass. And school isn’t even a contact sport (usually).
item.content:encoded: Thanks to daily Covid testing and regimented protocols, the new football season is underway. Meanwhile, most teachers, students, and parents are essentially waiting for the storm to pass. And school isn’t even a contact sport (usually).

item.title: "I Started Crying When I Realized How Beautiful the Universe Is” | People I (Mostly) Admire Ep. 2: Mayim Bialik
item.itunes:title: "I Started Crying When I Realized How Beautiful the Universe Is” | People I (Mostly) Admire Ep. 2: Mayim Bialik
item.description: She’s best known for playing neurobiologist Amy Farrah Fowler on The Big Bang Theory, but the award-winning actress has a rich life outside of her acting career, as a teacher, mother — and a real-life neuroscientist. Steve Levitt tries to learn more about this one-time academic and Hollywood non-conformist, who is both very similar to him and also quite his opposite.

item.title: America’s Hidden Duopoly (Ep. 356 Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: America’s Hidden Duopoly (Ep. 356 Rebroadcast)
item.description: We all know our political system is “broken” — but what if that’s not true? Some say the Republicans and Democrats constitute a wildly successful industry that has colluded to kill off competition, stifle reform, and drive the country apart. So what are you going to do about it?

item.title: 430. Will a Covid-19 Vaccine Change the Future of Medical Research?
item.itunes:title: Will a Covid-19 Vaccine Change the Future of Medical Research?
item.description: We explore the science, scalability, and (of course) economics surrounding the global vaccine race. Guests include the chief medical officer of the first U.S. firm to go to Phase 3 trials with a vaccine candidate; a former F.D.A. commissioner who’s been warning of a pandemic for years; and an economist who thinks Covid-19 may finally change how diseases are cured.
item.content:encoded: We explore the science, scalability, and (of course) economics surrounding the global vaccine race. Guests include the chief medical officer of the first U.S. firm to go to Phase 3 trials with a vaccine candidate; a former F.D.A. commissioner who’s been warning of a pandemic for years; and an economist who thinks Covid-19 may finally change how diseases are cured.
item.itunes:summary: We explore the science, scalability, and (of course) economics surrounding the global vaccine race. Guests include the chief medical officer of the first U.S. firm to go to Phase 3 trials with a vaccine candidate; a former F.D.A. commissioner who’s been warning of a pandemic for years; and an economist who thinks Covid-19 may finally change how diseases are cured.

item.title: Introducing “People I (Mostly) Admire"
item.itunes:title: Introducing “People I (Mostly) Admire"
item.description: A new interview show with host Steve Levitt. Today he speaks with the Harvard psychologist and linguist Steven Pinker. By cataloging the steady march of human progress, the self-declared “polite Canadian” has managed to enrage people on opposite ends of the political spectrum. Levitt tries to understand why.

item.title: The Economics of Sports Gambling (Ep. 388 Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: The Economics of Sports Gambling (Ep. 388 Rebroadcast)
item.description: What happens when tens of millions of fantasy-sports players are suddenly able to bet real money on real games? We’re about to find out. A recent Supreme Court decision has cleared the way to bring an estimated $300 billion in black-market sports betting into the light. We sort out the winners and losers.

item.title: 429. Is Economic Growth the Wrong Goal?
item.itunes:title: Is Economic Growth the Wrong Goal?
item.description: The endless pursuit of G.D.P., argues the economist Kate Raworth, shortchanges too many people and also trashes the planet. Economic theory, she says, “needs to be rewritten” — and Raworth has tried, in a book called Doughnut Economics. It has found an audience among reformers, and now the city of Amsterdam is going whole doughnut.

item.title: How the Supermarket Helped America Win the Cold War (Ep. 386 Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: How the Supermarket Helped America Win the Cold War (Ep. 386 Rebroadcast)
item.description: Aisle upon aisle of fresh produce, cheap meat, and sugary cereal — a delicious embodiment of free-market capitalism, right? Not quite. The supermarket was in fact the endpoint of the U.S. government’s battle for agricultural abundance against the U.S.S.R. Our farm policies were built to dominate, not necessarily to nourish — and we are still living with the consequences.

item.itunes:title: The Simple Economics of Saving the Amazon Rain Forest
item.description: Everyone agrees that massive deforestation is an environmental disaster. But most of the standard solutions — scolding the Brazilians, invoking universal morality — ignore the one solution that might actually work

item.itunes:title: Remembrance of Economic Crises Past

item.title: 424. How to Make Your Own Luck
item.itunes:title: How to Make Your Own Luck
item.description: Before she decided to become a poker pro, Maria Konnikova didn’t know how many cards are in a deck. But she did have a Ph.D. in psychology, a brilliant coach, and a burning desire to know whether life is driven more by skill or chance. She found some answers in poker — and in her new book The Biggest Bluff, she’s willing to tell us everything she learned.

item.itunes:title: How to Prevent Another Great Depression

item.title: 420. Which Jobs Will Come Back, and When?
item.itunes:title: Which Jobs Will Come Back, and When?

item.itunes:title: How to Make Meetings Less Terrible (Ep. 389 Rebroadcast)
item.description: In the U.S. alone, we hold 55 million meetings a day. Most of them are woefully unproductive, and tyrannize our offices. The revolution begins now — with better agendas, smaller invite lists, and an embrace of healthy conflict.

item.itunes:title: Will Covid-19 Spark a Cold War (or Worse) With China?
item.description: The U.S. spent the past few decades waiting for China to act like the global citizen it said it wanted to be. The waiting may be over.

item.title: 413. Who Gets the Ventilator?
item.itunes:title: Who Gets the Ventilator?
item.description: Should a nurse or doctor who gets sick treating Covid-19 patients have priority access to a potentially life-saving healthcare device? Americans aren’t used to rationing in medicine, but it’s time to think about it. We consult a lung specialist, a bioethicist, and (of course) an economist.

item.itunes:title: What Happens When Everyone Stays Home to Eat?
item.description: Covid-19 has shocked our food-supply system like nothing in modern history. We examine the winners, the losers, the unintended consequences — and just how much toilet paper one household really needs.

item.title: 411. Is $2 Trillion the Right Medicine for a Sick Economy?
item.itunes:title: Is $2 Trillion the Right Medicine for a Sick Economy?
item.description: Congress just passed the biggest aid package in modern history. We ask six former White House economic advisors and one U.S. Senator: Will it actually work? What are its best and worst features? Where does $2 trillion come from, and what are the long-term effects of all that government spending?

item.itunes:title: What Does Covid-19 Mean for Cities (and Marriages)?
item.description: There are a lot of upsides to urban density — but viral contagion is not one of them. Also: a nationwide lockdown will show if familiarity really breeds contempt. And: how to help your neighbor.

item.title: 409. The Side Effects of Social Distancing
item.itunes:title: The Side Effects of Social Distancing
item.description: In just a few weeks, the novel coronavirus has undone a century’s worth of our economic and social habits. What consequences will this have on our future — and is there a silver lining in this very black pandemic cloud?

item.title: Why Rent Control Doesn’t Work (Ep. 373 Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Why Rent Control Doesn’t Work (Ep. 373 Rebroadcast)
item.description: As cities become ever-more expensive, politicians and housing advocates keep calling for rent control. Economists think that’s a terrible idea. They say it helps a small (albeit noisy) group of renters, but keeps overall rents artificially high by disincentivizing new construction. So what happens next?

item.title: 408. Does Anyone Really Know What Socialism Is?
item.itunes:title: Does Anyone Really Know What Socialism Is?
item.description: Trump says it would destroy us. Sanders says it will save us. The majority of millennials would like it to replace capitalism. But what is “it”? We bring in the economists to sort things out and tell us what the U.S. can learn from the good (and bad) experiences of other (supposedly) socialist countries.

item.itunes:title: Is There Really a “Loneliness Epidemic”?
item.description: That’s what some health officials are saying, but the data aren’t so clear. We look into what’s known (and not known) about the prevalence and effects of loneliness — including the possible upsides.

item.title: 406. Can You Hear Me Now?
item.itunes:title: Can You Hear Me Now?
item.description: When he became chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Ajit Pai announced that he was going to take a “weed whacker” to Obama-era regulations. So far, he’s kept his promise, and earned the internet’s ire for reversing the agency’s position on net neutrality. Pai defends his actions and explains how the U.S. can “win” everything from the 5G race to the war on robocalls.

item.title: 404. Does the President Matter as Much as You Think?
item.itunes:title: Does the President Matter as Much as You Think?
item.description: We asked this same question nearly a decade ago. The answer then: probably not. But a lot has changed since then, and we’re three years into one of the most anomalous presidencies in American history. So once again we try to sort out presidential signal from noise. What we hear from legal and policy experts may leave you surprised, befuddled — and maybe infuriated.

item.title: How the San Francisco 49ers Stopped Being Losers (Ep. 350 Update)
item.itunes:title: How the San Francisco 49ers Stopped Being Losers (Ep. 350 Update)
item.description: One of the most storied (and valuable) sports franchises in the world had fallen far. So they decided to do a full reboot — and it worked: this week, they are headed back to the Super Bowl. Before the 2018 season, we sat down with the team’s owner, head coach, general manager, and players as they were plotting their turnaround. Here’s an update of that episode.

item.description: One prescription drug is keeping some addicts from dying. So why isn’t it more widespread? A story of regulation, stigma, and the potentially fatal faith in abstinence.

item.description: How pharma greed, government subsidies, and a push to make pain the “fifth vital sign” kicked off a crisis that costs $80 billion a year and has killed hundreds of thousands of Americans.

item.title: 334. 5 Psychology Terms You’re Probably Misusing (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: 5 Psychology Terms You’re Probably Misusing (Rebroadcast)
item.description: We all like to throw around terms that describe human behavior — “bystander apathy” and “steep learning curve” and “hard-wired.” Most of the time, they don’t actually mean what we think they mean. But don’t worry — the experts are getting it wrong, too.

item.description: There is strong evidence that exercise is wildly beneficial. There is even stronger evidence that most people hate to exercise. So if a pill could mimic the effects of working out, why wouldn’t we want to take it?

item.title: 400. How to Hate Taxes a Little Bit Less
item.itunes:title: How to Hate Taxes a Little Bit Less
item.description: Every year, Americans short the I.R.S. nearly half a trillion dollars. Most ideas to increase compliance are more stick than carrot — scary letters, audits, and penalties. But what if we gave taxpayers a chance to allocate how their money is spent, or even bribed them with a thank-you gift?

item.title: 399. Honey, I Grew the Economy
item.itunes:title: Honey, I Grew the Economy
item.description: Innovation experts have long overlooked where a lot of innovation actually happens. The personal computer, the mountain bike, the artificial pancreas — none of these came from some big R&D lab, but from users tinkering in their homes. Acknowledging this reality — and encouraging it — would be good for the economy (and the soul too).

item.title: 379. How to Change Your Mind (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: How to Change Your Mind (Rebroadcast)
item.description: There are a lot of barriers to changing your mind: ego, overconfidence, inertia — and cost. Politicians who flip-flop get mocked; family and friends who cross tribal borders are shunned. But shouldn’t we be encouraging people to change their minds? And how can we get better at it ourselves?

item.title: 397. How to Save $32 Million in One Hour
item.itunes:title: How to Save $32 Million in One Hour
item.description: For nearly a decade, governments have been using behavioral nudges to solve problems — and the strategy is catching on in healthcare, firefighting, and policing. But is that thinking too small? Could nudging be used to fight income inequality and achieve world peace? Recorded live in London, with commentary from Andy Zaltzman (The Bugle).

item.title: 395. Speak Softly and Carry Big Data
item.itunes:title: Speak Softly and Carry Big Data
item.description: Do economic sanctions work? Are big democracies any good at spreading democracy? What is the root cause of terrorism? It turns out that data analysis can help answer all these questions — and make better foreign-policy decisions. Guests include former Department of Defense officials Chuck Hagel and Michèle Flournoy and Chicago Project on Security and Threats researchers Robert Pape and Paul Poast. Recorded live in Chicago; Steve Levitt is co-host.

item.title: 393. Can Britain Get Its “Great” Back?
item.itunes:title: Can Britain Get Its “Great” Back?
item.description: It used to be a global capital of innovation, invention, and exploration. Now it’s best known for its messy European divorce. We visit London to see if the British spirit of discovery is still alive. Guests include the mayor of London, undersea explorers, a time-use researcher, and a theoretical physicist who helped Liverpool win the Champions League. Dan Schreiber from No Such Thing as a Fish rides shotgun.

item.title: 392. The Prime Minister Who Cried Brexit
item.itunes:title: The Prime Minister Who Cried Brexit
item.description: In 2016, David Cameron held a referendum on whether the U.K. should stay in the European Union. A longtime Euroskeptic, he nevertheless led the Remain campaign. So what did Cameron really want? We ask him that and much more — including why he left office as soon as his side lost and what he’d do differently if given another chance. (Hint: not much.)

item.itunes:title: The Economics of Sports Gambling
item.description: What happens when tens of millions of fantasy-sports players are suddenly able to bet real money on real games? We’re about to find out. item.title: 386. How the Supermarket Helped America Win the Cold War
item.itunes:title: How the Supermarket Helped America Win the Cold War
item.description: Aisle upon aisle of fresh produce, cheap meat, and sugary cereal — a delicious embodiment of free-market capitalism, right? Not quite. The supermarket was in fact the endpoint of the U.S. government’s battle for agricultural abundance against the U.S.S.R. Our farm policies were built to dominate, not necessarily to nourish — and we are still living with the consequences.

item.title: 385. What Do Nancy Pelosi, Taylor Swift, and Serena Williams Have in Common?
item.itunes:title: What Do Nancy Pelosi, Taylor Swift, and Serena Williams Have in Common?
item.description: They — along with a great many other high-achieving women — were all once Girl Scouts. So was Sylvia Acevedo. Raised in a poor, immigrant family, she was told that “girls like her” didn’t go to college. But she did, and then became a rocket scientist and tech executive. Now she’s C.E.O. of the very organization she credits with shaping her life. Acevedo tells us how the Girl Scouts are trying to stay relevant, why they’re suing the Boy Scouts, and how they sell so many cookies.

item.title: 384. Abortion and Crime, Revisited
item.itunes:title: Abortion and Crime, Revisited
item.description: The controversial theory linking Roe v. Wade to a massive crime drop is back in the spotlight as several states introduce abortion restrictions. Steve Levitt and John Donohue discuss their original research, the challenges to its legitimacy, and their updated analysis. Also: what this means for abortion policy, crime policy, and having intelligent conversations about contentious topics.

item.title: 379. How to Change Your Mind
item.itunes:title: How to Change Your Mind
item.description: There are a lot of barriers to changing your mind: ego, overconfidence, inertia — and cost. Politicians who flip-flop get mocked; family and friends who cross tribal borders are shunned. But shouldn’t we be encouraging people to change their minds? And how can we get better at it ourselves?

item.title: 323. Here’s Why All Your Projects Are Always Late — and What to Do About It (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Here’s Why All Your Projects Are Always Late — and What to Do About It (Rebroadcast)
item.description: Whether it’s a giant infrastructure plan or a humble kitchen renovation, it’ll inevitably take way too long and cost way too much. That’s because you suffer from “the planning fallacy.” (You also have an “optimism bias” and a bad case of overconfidence.) But don’t worry: we’ve got the solution.

item.title: 378. 23andMe (and You, and Everyone Else)
item.itunes:title: 23andMe (and You, and Everyone Else)
item.description: The revolution in home DNA testing is giving consumers important, possibly life-changing information. It’s also building a gigantic database that could lead to medical breakthroughs. But how will you deal with upsetting news? What if your privacy is compromised? And are you prepared to have your DNA monetized? We speak with Anne Wojcicki, founder and C.E.O. of 23andMe.

item.title: 377. The $1.5 Trillion Question: How to Fix Student-Loan Debt?
item.itunes:title: The $1.5 Trillion Question: How to Fix Student-Loan Debt?
item.description: As the cost of college skyrocketed, it created a debt burden that’s putting a drag on the economy. One possible solution: shifting the risk of debt away from students and onto investors looking for a cut of the graduates’ earning power.

item.title: 375. The Most Interesting Fruit in the World
item.itunes:title: The Most Interesting Fruit in the World
item.description: The banana used to be a luxury good. Now it’s the most popular fruit in the U.S. and elsewhere. But the production efficiencies that made it so cheap have also made it vulnerable to a deadly fungus that may wipe out the one variety most of us eat. Scientists do have a way to save it — but will Big Banana let them?

item.title: 374. How Spotify Saved the Music Industry (But Not Necessarily Musicians)
item.itunes:title: How Spotify Saved the Music Industry (But Not Necessarily Musicians)
item.description: Daniel Ek, a 23-year-old Swede who grew up on pirated music, made the record labels an offer they couldn’t refuse: a legal platform to stream all the world’s music. Spotify reversed the labels’ fortunes, made Ek rich, and thrilled millions of music fans. But what has it done for all those musicians stuck in the long tail?

item.title: 373. Why Rent Control Doesn’t Work
item.itunes:title: Why Rent Control Doesn’t Work
item.description: As cities become ever-more expensive, politicians and housing advocates keep calling for rent control. Economists think that’s a terrible idea. They say it helps a small (albeit noisy) group of renters, but keeps overall rents artificially high by disincentivizing new construction. So what happens next?

item.title: 371. A Free-Trade Democrat in the Trump White House
item.itunes:title: A Free-Trade Democrat in the Trump White House
item.description: For years, Gary Cohn thought he’d be the next C.E.O. of Goldman Sachs. Instead, he became the “adult in the room” in a chaotic administration. Cohn talks about the fights he won, the fights he lost, and the fights he was no longer willing to have. Also: why he and Trump are still on speaking terms even after he reportedly called the president “a professional liar.”

item.title: 364. Inside the Sports-Industrial Complex
item.itunes:title: Inside the Sports-Industrial Complex
item.description: For most of us, the athletes are what make sports interesting. But if you own the team or run the league, your players are essentially very expensive migrant workers who eat into your profits. We talk to N.F.L., N.B.A., and U.F.C. executives about labor costs, viewership numbers, legalized gambling, and the rise of e-sports. (Ep. 5 of “The Hidden Side of Sports” series.)

item.title: 362. Why Is This Man Running for President?
item.itunes:title: Why Is This Man Running for President?
item.description: In the American Dream sweepstakes, Andrew Yang was a pretty big winner. But for every winner, he came to realize, there are thousands upon thousands of losers — a “war on normal people,” he calls it. Here’s what he plans to do about it.

item.title: 345. How to Be Happy (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: How to Be Happy (Rebroadcast)
item.description: The U.N.’s World Happiness Report — created to curtail our unhealthy obsession with G.D.P. — is dominated every year by the Nordic countries. We head to Denmark to learn the secrets of this happiness epidemic (and to see if we should steal them).

item.title: 247. How to Win Games and Beat People (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: How to Win Games and Beat People (Rebroadcast)
item.description: Games are as old as civilization itself, and some people think they have huge social value regardless of whether you win or lose. Tom Whipple is not one of those people. That’s why he consulted an army of preposterously overqualified experts to find the secret to winning any game.

item.title: 340. People Aren’t Dumb. The World Is Hard. (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: People Aren’t Dumb. The World Is Hard. (Rebroadcast)
item.description: You wouldn’t think you could win a Nobel Prize for showing that humans tend to make irrational decisions. But that’s what Richard Thaler has done. The founder of behavioral economics describes his unlikely route to success; his reputation for being lazy; and his efforts to fix the world — one nudge at a time.

item.title: 360. Is the Protestant Work Ethic Real?
item.itunes:title: Is the Protestant Work Ethic Real?
item.description: In the early 20th century, Max Weber argued that Protestantism created wealth. Finally, there are data to prove if he was right. All it took were some missionary experiments in the Philippines and a clever map-matching trick that goes back to 16th-century Germany.

item.title: 285. There’s a War on Sugar. Is It Justified? (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: There’s a War on Sugar. Is It Justified? (Rebroadcast)
item.description: Some people argue that sugar should be regulated, like alcohol and tobacco, on the grounds that it’s addictive and toxic. How much sense does that make? We hear from a regulatory advocate, an evidence-based skeptic, a former F.D.A. commissioner — and the organizers of Milktoberfest.

item.description: It began as a post-war dream for a more collaborative and egalitarian workplace. It has evolved into a nightmare of noise and discomfort. Can the open office be saved, or should we all just be working from home?

item.title: 357. Can an Industrial Giant Become a Tech Darling?
item.itunes:title: Can an Industrial Giant Become a Tech Darling?
item.description: The Ford Motor Company is ditching its legacy sedans, doubling down on trucks, and trying to steer its stock price out of a long skid. But C.E.O. Jim Hackett has even bigger plans: to turn a century-old automaker into the nucleus of a “transportation operating system.” Is Hackett just whistling past the graveyard, or does he see what others can’t?

item.title: 356. America’s Hidden Duopoly

item.title: 355. Where Does Creativity Come From (and Why Do Schools Kill It Off)?
item.itunes:title: Where Does Creativity Come From (and Why Do Schools Kill It Off)?
item.description: Family environments and “diversifying experiences” (including the early death of a parent); intrinsic versus extrinsic motivations; schools that value assessments, but don't assess the things we value. All these elements factor into the long, mysterious march towards a creative life. To learn more, we examine the early years of Ai Weiwei, Rosanne Cash, Elvis Costello, Maira Kalman, Wynton Marsalis, Jennifer Egan, and others. (Ep. 2 of the “How to Be Creative” series.)

item.title: 354. How to Be Creative
item.itunes:title: How to Be Creative
item.description: There are thousands of books on the subject, but what do we actually know about creativity? In this new series, we talk to the researchers who study it as well as artists, inventors, and pathbreakers who live it every day: Ai Weiwei, James Dyson, Elvis Costello, Jennifer Egan, Rosanne Cash, Wynton Marsalis, Maira Kalman, and more. (Ep. 1 of the “How to Be Creative” series.)

item.title: 352. Can This Man Stop a Trade War?
item.itunes:title: Can This Man Stop a Trade War?
item.description: The World Trade Organization is the referee for 164 trading partners, each with their own political and economic agendas. Lately, those agendas have gotten more complicated — especially with President Trump’s tariff blitz. Roberto Azevêdo, head of the W.T.O., tells us why it’s so hard to balance protectionism and globalism; what’s really behind the loss of jobs; and what he’d say to Trump (if he ever gets the chance).

item.title: 351. Here’s Why You’re Not an Elite Athlete
item.itunes:title: Here’s Why You’re Not an Elite Athlete
item.description: There are a lot of factors that go into greatness, many of which are not obvious. A variety of Olympic and professional athletes tell us how they made it and what they sacrificed to get there. And if you can identify the sport most likely to get a kid into a top college — well then, touché! (Ep. 3 of “The Hidden Side of Sports” series.)

item.title: 350. How to Stop Being a Loser
item.itunes:title: How to Stop Being a Loser
item.description: The San Francisco 49ers, one of the most valuable sports franchises in the world, also used to be one of the best. But they’ve been losing lately — a lot — and one of their players launched a controversy by taking a knee during the national anthem. So why is everyone there so optimistic? To find out, we speak with the team’s owner, head coach, general manager, and star players, including their new $137.5 million quarterback. (Ep. 2 of “The Hidden Side of Sports” series.)

item.title: 349. How Sports Became Us
item.itunes:title: How Sports Became Us
item.description: Dollar-wise, the sports industry is surprisingly small, about the same size as the cardboard-box industry. So why does it make so much noise? Because it reflects — and often amplifies — just about every political, economic, and social issue of the day. Introducing a new series, “The Hidden Side of Sports.”
item.content:encoded: Dollar-wise, the sports industry is surprisingly small, about the same size as the cardboard-box industry. So why does it make so much noise? item.title: 348. Is the Government More Entrepreneurial Than You Think?
item.itunes:title: Is the Government More Entrepreneurial Than You Think?
item.description: We all know the standard story: our economy would be more dynamic if only the government would get out of the way. The economist Mariana Mazzucato says we’ve got that story backward. She argues that the government, by funding so much early-stage research, is hugely responsible for big successes in tech, pharma, energy, and more. But the government also does a terrible job in claiming credit — and, more important, getting a return on its investment.

item.title: 345. How to Be Happy
item.itunes:title: How to Be Happy
item.description: The U.N.’s World Happiness Report — created to curtail our unhealthy obsession with G.D.P. — is dominated every year by the Nordic countries. We head to Denmark to learn the secrets of this happiness epidemic (and to see if we should steal them).

item.title: 344. Who Decides How Much a Life Is Worth?
item.itunes:title: Who Decides How Much a Life Is Worth?
item.description: After every mass shooting or terrorist attack, victims and survivors receive a huge outpouring of support — including a massive pool of compensation money. How should that money be allocated? We speak with the man who’s done that job after many tragedies, including 9/11. The hard part, it turns out, isn’t attaching a dollar figure to each victim; the hard part is acknowledging that dollars can’t heal the pain.

item.title: 342. Has Lance Armstrong Finally Come Clean?
item.itunes:title: Has Lance Armstrong Finally Come Clean?
item.description: He was once the most lionized athlete on the planet, with seven straight Tour de France wins and a victory over cancer too. Then the doping charges caught up with him. When he finally confessed to Oprah, he admits, “it didn’t go well at all.” That’s because he wasn’t actually contrite yet. Now, five years later, he says he is. Do you believe him?

item.title: 340. People Aren’t Dumb. The World Is Hard.
item.itunes:title: People Aren’t Dumb. The World Is Hard.
item.description: You wouldn’t think you could win a Nobel Prize for showing that humans tend to make irrational decisions. But that’s what Richard Thaler has done. The founder of behavioral economics describes his unlikely route to success; his reputation for being lazy; and his efforts to fix the world — one nudge at a time.

item.title: 337. How to Build a Smart City
item.itunes:title: How to Build a Smart City
item.description: We are in the midst of a historic (and wholly unpredicted) rise in urbanization. But it's hard to retrofit old cities for the 21st century. Enter Dan Doctoroff. The man who helped modernize New York City — and tried to bring the Olympics there — is now C.E.O. of a Google-funded startup that is building, from scratch, the city of the future.

item.title: 325. How to Train Your Dragon Child
item.itunes:title: How to Train Your Dragon Child
item.description: Every 12 years, there's a spike in births among certain communities across the globe, including the U.S. Why? Because the Year of the Dragon, according to Chinese folk belief, confers power, fortune, and more. We look at what happens to Dragon babies when they grow up, and why timing your kid's birth based on the zodiac isn't as ridiculous it sounds.

item.title: 323. Here’s Why All Your Projects Are Always Late — and What to Do About It
item.itunes:title: Here’s Why All Your Projects Are Always Late — and What to Do About It
item.description: Whether it's a giant infrastructure plan or a humble kitchen renovation, it'll inevitably take way too long and cost way too much. That's because you suffer from “the planning fallacy.” (You also have an “optimism bias” and a bad case of overconfidence.) But don't worry: we've got the solution.

item.title: 228. Does “Early Education” Come Way Too Late? (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Does “Early Education” Come Way Too Late? (Rebroadcast)
item.description: In our collective zeal to reform schools and close the achievement gap, we may have lost sight of where most learning really happens — at home.

item.title: 320. ​Letting Go
item.itunes:title: ​Letting Go
item.description: If you're a C.E.O., there are a lot of ways to leave your job, from abrupt firing to carefully planned succession (which may still go spectacularly wrong). In this final episode of our "Secret Life of a C.E.O." series, we hear those stories and many more. Also: what happens when you no longer have a corner office to go to — and how will you spend all that money?​

item.title: 319. After the Glass Ceiling, a Glass Cliff
item.itunes:title: After the Glass Ceiling, a Glass Cliff
item.description: Only 5 percent of Fortune 500 companies are run by women. Why? Research shows that female executives are more likely to be put in charge of firms that are already in crisis. Are they being set up to fail? (Part 5 of a special series, "The Secret Life of C.E.O.'s.")

item.title: 318. It’s Your Problem Now
item.itunes:title: It’s Your Problem Now
item.description: No, it's not your fault the economy crashed. Or that consumer preferences changed. Or that new technologies have blown apart your business model. But if you're the C.E.O., it is your problem. So what are you going to do about it? First-hand stories of disaster (and triumph) from Mark Zuckerberg, Steve Ballmer, Satya Nadella, Jack Welch, Ellen Pao, Richard Branson, and more. (Part 4 of a special series, "The Secret Life of C.E.O.'s.")

item.title: 317. What Can Uber Teach Us About the Gender Pay Gap?
item.itunes:title: What Can Uber Teach Us About the Gender Pay Gap?
item.description: The gig economy offers the ultimate flexibility to set your own hours. That's why economists thought it would help eliminate the gender pay gap. A new study, using data from over a million Uber drivers, finds the story isn't so simple.

item.title: 275. An Egghead’s Guide to the Super Bowl (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: An Egghead’s Guide to the Super Bowl (Rebroadcast)
item.description: We assembled a panel of smart dudes -- a two-time Super Bowl champ; a couple of N.F.L. linemen, including one who's getting a math Ph.D. at MIT; and our resident economist -- to tell you what to watch for, whether you're a football fanatic or a total newbie.

item.title: 316. “I Wasn’t Stupid Enough to Say This Could Be Done Overnight”
item.itunes:title: “I Wasn’t Stupid Enough to Say This Could Be Done Overnight”
item.description: Indra Nooyi became C.E.O. of PepsiCo just in time for a global financial meltdown. She also had a portfolio full of junk food just as the world decided that junk food is borderline toxic. Here's the story of how she overhauled that portfolio, stared down activist investors, and learned to "leave the crown in the garage." (Part 3 of a special series, "The Secret Life of C.E.O.'s")

item.title: 315. How to Become a C.E.O.
item.itunes:title: How to Become a C.E.O.
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg's dentist dad was an early adopter of digital x-rays. Jack Welch blew the roof off a factory. Carol Bartz was a Wisconsin farm girl who got into computers. No two C.E.O.'s have the same origin story — so we tell them all! How the leaders of Facebook, G.E., Yahoo!, PepsiCo, Microsoft, Virgin, the Carlyle Group, Reddit, and Bridgewater Associates made it to the top. (Part 2 of a special series, "The Secret Life of C.E.O.'s.")

item.title: 314. What Does a C.E.O. Actually Do?
item.itunes:title: What Does a C.E.O. Actually Do?
item.description: They're paid a fortune — but for what, exactly? What makes a good C.E.O. — and how can you even tell? Is "leadership science" a real thing — or just airport-bookstore mumbo jumbo? We put these questions to Mark Zuckerberg, Richard Branson, Indra Nooyi, Satya Nadella, Jack Welch, Ray Dalio, Carol Bartz, David Rubenstein, and Ellen Pao. (Part 1 of a special series, "The Secret Life of C.E.O.'s.")

item.title: 313. How to Be a Modern Democrat — and Win
item.itunes:title: How to Be a Modern Democrat — and Win
item.description: Gina Raimondo, the governor of tiny Rhode Island, has taken on unions, boosted big business, and made friends with Republicans. She is also one of just 15 Democratic governors in the country. Would there be more of them if there were more like her?

item.title: 280. Why Is My Life So Hard? (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Why Is My Life So Hard? (Rebroadcast)
item.description: Most of us feel we face more headwinds and obstacles than everyone else — which breeds resentment. We also undervalue the tailwinds that help us — which leaves us ungrateful and unhappy. How can we avoid this trap?

item.itunes:author: Freakonomics Radio + Stitcher

item.title: 266. Trust Me (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Trust Me (Rebroadcast)
item.description: Societies where people trust one another are healthier and wealthier. In the U.S. (and the U.K. and elsewhere), social trust has been falling for decades — in part because our populations are more diverse. What can we do to fix it?
item.content:encoded: Societies where people trust one another are healthier and wealthier. In the U.S. (and the U.K. and elsewhere), social trust has been falling for decades — in part because our populations are more diverse. What can we do to fix it?

item.title: 209. Make Me a Match (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Make Me a Match (Rebroadcast)
item.description: Sure, markets generally work well. But for some transactions — like school admissions and organ transplants — money alone can't solve the problem. That's when you need a market-design wizard like Al Roth.

item.title: 312. Not Your Grandmother’s I.M.F.
item.itunes:title: Not Your Grandmother’s I.M.F.
item.description: The International Monetary Fund has long been the "lender of last resort" for economies in crisis. Christine Lagarde, who runs the institution, would like to prevent those crises from ever happening. She tells us her plans.

item.title: 311. Why Is the Live-Event Ticket Market So Screwed Up?
item.itunes:title: Why Is the Live-Event Ticket Market So Screwed Up?
item.description: The public has almost no chance to buy good tickets to the best events. Ticket brokers, meanwhile, make huge profits on the secondary markets. Here's the story of how this market got so dysfunctional, how it can be fixed – and why it probably won't be.
item.content:encoded: The public has almost no chance to buy good tickets to the best events. Ticket brokers, meanwhile, make huge profits on the secondary markets. Here's the story of how this market got so dysfunctional, how it can be fixed – and why it probably won't be.

item.title: 310. Are We Running Out of Ideas?
item.itunes:title: Are We Running Out of Ideas?
item.description: Economists have a hard time explaining why productivity growth has been shrinking. One theory: true innovation has gotten much harder – and much more expensive. So what should we do next?
item.content:encoded: Economists have a hard time explaining why productivity growth has been shrinking. One theory: true innovation has gotten much harder – and much more expensive. So what should we do next?

item.title: 12. Is America Ready for a “No-Lose Lottery”? (Update)
item.itunes:title: Is America Ready for a “No-Lose Lottery”? (Update)
item.description: Most people don't enjoy the simple, boring act of putting money in a savings account. But we do love to play the lottery. So what if you combine the two, creating a new kind of savings account with a lottery payout?
item.content:encoded: Most people don't enjoy the simple, boring act of putting money in a savings account. But we do love to play the lottery. So what if you combine the two, creating a new kind of savings account with a lottery payout?

item.title: 309. Nurses to the Rescue!
item.itunes:title: Nurses to the Rescue!
item.description: They are the most-trusted profession in America (and with good reason). They are critical to patient outcomes (especially in primary care). Could the growing army of nurse practitioners be an answer to the doctor shortage? The data say yes but — big surprise — doctors' associations say no.

item.title: 308. How Can I Do the Most Social Good With $100? And Other FREAK-quently Asked Questions
item.itunes:title: How Can I Do the Most Social Good With $100? And Other FREAK-quently Asked Questions
item.description: Dubner and his Freakonomics co-author Steve Levitt answer your questions about crime, traffic, real-estate agents, the Ph.D. glut, and how to not get eaten by a bear.

item.description: In this live episode of "Tell Me Something I Don't Know," you'll learn about carcass balancing, teen sleeping, and brand naming. Joining Stephen J. Dubner as co-host is Alex Wagner (CBS This Morning Saturday); author A.J. Jacobs (It's All Relative) is the live fact-checker.

item.itunes:title: Thinking Is Expensive. Who’s Supposed to Pay for It?
item.description: Corporations and rich people donate billions to their favorite think tanks and foundations. Should we be grateful for their generosity — or suspicious of their motives?

item.title: 306. How to Launch a Behavior-Change Revolution
item.itunes:title: How to Launch a Behavior-Change Revolution
item.description: Academic studies are nice, and so are Nobel Prizes. But to truly prove the value of a new idea, you have to unleash it to the masses. That's what a dream team of social scientists is doing — and we sat in as they drew up their game plan.

item.title: 305. The Demonization of Gluten
item.itunes:title: The Demonization of Gluten
item.description: Celiac disease is thought to affect roughly one percent of the population. The good news: it can be treated by quitting gluten. The bad news: many celiac patients haven't been diagnosed. The weird news: millions of people without celiac disease have quit gluten – which may be a big mistake.

item.title: 304. What Are the Secrets of the German Economy — and Should We Steal Them?
item.itunes:title: What Are the Secrets of the German Economy — and Should We Steal Them?
item.description: Smart government policies, good industrial relations, and high-end products have helped German manufacturing beat back the threats of globalization.

item.title: “Tell Me Something I Don't Know” on the topic of Behavior Change (Special Feature)
item.itunes:title: “Tell Me Something I Don't Know” on the topic of Behavior Change (Special Feature)
item.description: Stephen J. Dubner hosts an episode full of the world's most renowned behavior change experts, including Colin Camerer, Ayelet Fishbach, David Laibson, Max Bazerman, Katy Milkman, and Kevin Volpp. Angela Duckworth (psychologist and author of Grit) is our special guest co-host, with Mike Maughan (head of global insights at Qualtrics) as real-time fact-checker.

item.title: 303. Why Larry Summers Is the Economist Everyone Hates to Love
item.itunes:title: Why Larry Summers Is the Economist Everyone Hates to Love
item.description: He's been U.S. Treasury Secretary, a chief economist for the Obama White House and the World Bank, and president of Harvard. He's one of the most brilliant economists of his generation (and perhaps the most irascible). And he thinks the Trump Administration is wrong on just about everything.

item.itunes:title: Why Learn Esperanto?
item.description: A language invented in the 19th century, and meant to be universal, it never really caught on. So why does a group of Esperantists from around the world gather once a year to celebrate their bond?

item.title: 301. What Would Be the Best Universal Language? (Earth 2.0 Series)
item.itunes:title: What Would Be the Best Universal Language? (Earth 2.0 Series)
item.description: We explore votes for English, Indonesian, and … Esperanto! The search for a common language goes back millennia, but so much still gets lost in translation. Will technology finally solve that?

item.itunes:title: Why Don’t We All Speak the Same Language? (Earth 2.0 Series)
item.description: There are 7,000 languages spoken on Earth. What are the costs — and benefits — of our modern-day Tower of Babel?

item.title: 299. "How Much Brain Damage Do I Have?"
item.itunes:title: "How Much Brain Damage Do I Have?"
item.description: John Urschel was the only player in the N.F.L. simultaneously getting a math Ph.D. at M.I.T. But after a new study came out linking football to brain damage, he abruptly retired. Here's the inside story — and a look at how we make decisions in the face of risk versus uncertainty.

item.title: 270. Bad Medicine, Part 3: Death by Diagnosis (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Bad Medicine, Part 3: Death by Diagnosis (Rebroadcast)
item.description: By some estimates, medical error is the third-leading cause of death in the U.S. How can that be? And what's to be done? Our third and final episode in this series offers some encouraging answers.

item.title: 269. Bad Medicine, Part 2: (Drug) Trials and Tribulations (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Bad Medicine, Part 2: (Drug) Trials and Tribulations (Rebroadcast)
item.description: How do so many ineffective and even dangerous drugs make it to market? One reason is that clinical trials are often run on "dream patients" who aren't representative of a larger population. On the other hand, sometimes the only thing worse than being excluded from a drug trial is being included.

item.title: 268. Bad Medicine, Part 1: The Story of 98.6 (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: Bad Medicine, Part 1: The Story of 98.6 (Rebroadcast)
item.description: We tend to think of medicine as a science, but for most of human history it has been scientific-ish at best. In the first episode of a three-part series, we look at the grotesque mistakes produced by centuries of trial-and-error, and ask whether the new era of evidence-based medicine is the solution.

item.title: 256. What Are You Waiting For? (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: What Are You Waiting For? (Rebroadcast)
item.description: Standing in line represents a particularly sloppy — and frustrating — way for supply and demand to meet. Why haven't we found a better way to get what we want? Is it possible that we secretly enjoy waiting in line? And might it even be (gulp) good for us?

item.description: The bad news: roughly 70 percent of Americans are financially illiterate. The good news: all the important stuff can fit on one index card. Here's how to become your own financial superhero.

item.title: 297. The Stupidest Thing You Can Do With Your Money
item.itunes:title: The Stupidest Thing You Can Do With Your Money
item.description: It's hard enough to save for a house, tuition, or retirement. So why are we willing to pay big fees for subpar investment returns? Enter the low-cost index fund. The revolution will not be monetized.

item.title: 296. These Shoes Are Killing Me!
item.itunes:title: These Shoes Are Killing Me!
item.description: The human foot is an evolutionary masterpiece, far more functional than we give it credit for. So why do we encase it in "a coffin" (as one foot scholar calls it) that stymies so much of its ability — and may create more problems than it solves?

item.title: 294. The Fracking Boom, a Baby Boom, and the Retreat From Marriage
item.itunes:title: The Fracking Boom, a Baby Boom, and the Retreat From Marriage
item.description: Over 40 percent of U.S. births are to unmarried mothers, and the numbers are especially high among the less-educated. Why? One argument is that the decline in good manufacturing jobs led to a decline in "marriageable" men. Surely the fracking boom reversed that trend, right?

item.title: 293. Why Hate the Koch Brothers? (Part 2)
item.itunes:title: Why Hate the Koch Brothers? (Part 2)
item.description: Charles Koch, the mega-billionaire CEO of Koch Industries and half of the infamous political machine, sees himself as a classical liberal. So why do most Democrats hate him so much? In a rare series of interviews, he explains his political awakening, his management philosophy, and why he supports legislation that goes against his self-interest.

item.title: "Tell Me Something I Don't Know" on the topic of Rivalry
item.itunes:title: "Tell Me Something I Don't Know" on the topic of Rivalry
item.description: Steve Levitt, Scott Turow and Bridget Gainer are panelists. For the "Freakonomics" co-author, the attorney and novelist, and the Cook County commissioner it's "game on!" as they tackle competition of all kinds: athletic, sexual, geopolitical, and the little-known battle between butter and margarine that landed in the Supreme Court. WBEZ's Tricia Bobeda, co-host of the "Nerdette" podcast, is fact-checker.

item.title: 289. How Stupid Is Our Obsession With Lawns?
item.itunes:title: How Stupid Is Our Obsession With Lawns?
item.description: Nearly two percent of America is grassy green. Sure, lawns are beautiful and useful and they smell great. But are the costs — financial, environmental and otherwise — worth the benefits?

item.title: 288. Are the Rich Really Less Generous Than the Poor?
item.itunes:title: Are the Rich Really Less Generous Than the Poor?
item.description: A series of academic studies suggest that the wealthy are, to put it bluntly, selfish jerks. It's an easy narrative to swallow — but is it true? A trio of economists set out to test the theory. All it took was a Dutch postal worker's uniform, some envelopes stuffed with cash, and a slight sense of the absurd.

item.title: 287. Hoopers! Hoopers! Hoopers!
item.itunes:title: Hoopers! Hoopers! Hoopers!
item.description: As CEO of Microsoft, Steve Ballmer was famous for over-the-top enthusiasm. Now he's brought that same passion to the N.B.A. -- and to a pet project called USAFacts, which performs a sort of fiscal colonoscopy on the American government.

item.title: 286. How Big is My Penis? (And Other Things We Ask Google)
item.itunes:title: How Big is My Penis? (And Other Things We Ask Google)
item.description: On the Internet, people say all kinds of things they'd never say aloud -- about sex and race, about their true wants and fears. Seth Stephens-Davidowitz has spent years parsing the data. His conclusion: our online searches are the reflection of our true selves. In the real world, everybody lies.

item.description: Some people argue that sugar should be regulated, like alcohol and tobacco, on the grounds that it's addictive and toxic. How much sense does that make? We hear from a regulatory advocate, an evidence-based skeptic, a former FDA commissioner — and the organizers of Milktoberfest.

item.title: 283. What Would Our Economy Look Like? (Earth 2.0 Series)
item.itunes:title: What Would Our Economy Look Like? (Earth 2.0 Series)
item.description: If we could reboot the planet and create new systems and institutions from scratch, would they be any better than what we've blundered our way into through trial and error? This is the first of a series of episodes that we'll release over several months. Today we start with — what else? — economics. You'll hear from Nobel laureate Angus Deaton, the poverty-fighting superhero Jeff Sachs; and many others.

item.title: 282. Could Solving This One Problem Solve All the Others?
item.itunes:title: Could Solving This One Problem Solve All the Others?
item.description: The biggest problem with humanity is humans themselves. Too often, we make choices — what we eat, how we spend our money and time — that undermine our well-being. An all-star team of academic researchers thinks it has the solution: perfecting the science of behavior change. Will it work?

item.title: 194. How Safe Is Your Job? (Rebroadcast)

item.description: Economists preach the gospel of "creative destruction," whereby new industries -- and jobs -- replace the old ones. But has creative destruction become too destructive?

item.title: 279. Why Is My Life So Hard?
item.itunes:title: Why Is My Life So Hard?
item.description: Most of us feel we face more headwinds and obstacles than everyone else — which breeds resentment. We also undervalue the tailwinds that help us — which leaves us ungrateful and unhappy. How can we avoid this trap?

item.title: 278. Chuck E. Cheese’s: Where a Kid Can Learn Price Theory
item.itunes:title: Chuck E. Cheese’s: Where a Kid Can Learn Price Theory
item.description: The pizza-and-gaming emporium prides itself on affordability, which means its arcade games are really cheap to play. Does that lead to kids hogging the best games — and parents starting those infamous YouTube brawls?

item.title: 277. The Taboo Trifecta
item.itunes:title: The Taboo Trifecta
item.description: The serial entrepreneur Miki Agrawal loves to talk about the bodily functions that make most people flinch. That's why she's building a business around the three P's: periods, pee, and poop.

item.title: 276. No Hollywood Ending for the Visual-Effects Industry
item.itunes:title: No Hollywood Ending for the Visual-Effects Industry
item.description: In their chase for a global audience, American movie studios spend billions to make their films look amazing. But almost none of those dollars stay in America. What would it take to bring those jobs back -- and would it be worth it?

item.title: 275. Professor Hendryx vs. Big Coal
item.itunes:title: Professor Hendryx vs. Big Coal
item.description: What happens when a public-health researcher deep in coal country argues that mountaintop mining endangers the entire community? Hint: it doesn't go very well.

item.title: 246. How to Get More Grit in Your Life
item.itunes:title: How to Get More Grit in Your Life
item.description: The psychologist Angela Duckworth argues that a person's level of stick-to-itiveness is directly related to their level of success. No big surprise there. But grit, she says, isn't something you're born with — it can be learned. Here's how.

item.title: 274. An Egghead’s Guide to the Super Bowl
item.itunes:title: An Egghead’s Guide to the Super Bowl
item.description: We assembled a panel of smart dudes -- a two-time Super Bowl champ; a couple of NFL linemen, including one who's getting a math Ph.D. at MIT; and our resident economist -- to tell you what to watch for, whether you're a football fanatic or a total newbie.

item.title: 273. Did China Eat America’s Jobs?
item.itunes:title: Did China Eat America’s Jobs?
item.description: For years, economists promised that global free trade would be mostly win-win. Now they admit the pace of change has been "traumatic." This has already led to a political insurrection -- so what's next?

item.title: 272. Is the American Dream Really Dead?
item.itunes:title: Is the American Dream Really Dead?
item.description: Just a few decades ago, more than 90 percent of 30-year-olds earned more than their parents had earned at the same age. Now it's only about 50 percent. What happened -- and what can be done about it?

item.title: 272. Trevor Noah Has a Lot to Say
item.itunes:title: Trevor Noah Has a Lot to Say
item.description: The Daily Show host grew up as a poor, mixed-race South African kid going to three churches every Sunday. So he has a sui generis view of America — especially on race, politics, and religion — and he's not afraid to speak his mind.

item.title: 271. The Men Who Started a Thinking Revolution
item.itunes:title: The Men Who Started a Thinking Revolution
item.description: Starting in the late 1960s, the Israeli psychologists Amos Tversky and Danny Kahneman began to redefine how the human mind actually works. Michael Lewis's new book The Undoing Project explains how the movement they started -- now known as behavioral economics -- has had such a profound effect on academia, governments, and society at large.

item.title: 244. How to Become Great at Just About Anything (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: How to Become Great at Just About Anything (Rebroadcast)
item.description: What if the thing we call "talent" is grotesquely overrated? And what if deliberate practice is the secret to excellence? Those are the claims of the research psychologist Anders Ericsson, who has been studying the science of expertise for decades. He tells us everything he's learned.

item.title: 243. How to Be More Productive (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: How to Be More Productive (Rebroadcast)
item.description: In this busy time of year, we could all use some tips on how to get more done in less time. First, however, a warning: there's a big difference between being busy and being productive.

item.title: 270. Bad Medicine, Part 3: Death by Diagnosis
item.itunes:title: Bad Medicine, Part 3: Death by Diagnosis
item.description: By some estimates, medical error is the third-leading cause of death in the U.S. How can that be? And what's to be done? Our third and final episode in this series offers some encouraging answers.

item.title: 269. Bad Medicine, Part 2: (Drug) Trials and Tribulations
item.itunes:title: Bad Medicine, Part 2: (Drug) Trials and Tribulations
item.description: How do so many ineffective and even dangerous drugs make it to market? One reason is that clinical trials are often run on "dream patients" who aren't representative of a larger population. On the other hand, sometimes the only thing worse than being excluded from a drug trial is being included.

item.title: 268. Bad Medicine, Part 1: The Story of 98.6
item.itunes:title: Bad Medicine, Part 1: The Story of 98.6
item.description: We tend to think of medicine as a science, but for most of human history it has been scientific-ish at best. In the first episode of a three-part series, we look at the grotesque mistakes produced by centuries of trial-and-error, and ask whether the new era of evidence-based medicine is the solution.

item.title: 239. The No-Tipping Point (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: The No-Tipping Point (Rebroadcast)
item.description: The restaurant business model is warped: kitchen wages are too low to hire cooks, while diners are put in charge of paying the waitstaff. So what happens if you eliminate tipping, raise menu prices, and redistribute the wealth? New York restaurant maverick Danny Meyer is about to find out.

item.title: 267. How to Make a Bad Decision
item.itunes:title: How to Make a Bad Decision
item.description: Some of our most important decisions are shaped by something as random as the order in which we make them. The gambler's fallacy, as it's known, affects loan officers, federal judges -- and probably you too. How to avoid it? The first step is to admit just how fallible we all are.

item.title: Introducing Stephen J. Dubner's new podcast, "Tell Me Something I Don't Know"
item.itunes:title: Introducing Stephen J. Dubner's new podcast, "Tell Me Something I Don't Know"
item.description: "Tell Me Something I Don't Know" is a live game show hosted by Stephen J. Dubner of "Freakonomics Radio." He has always had a mission: to tell you the things you thought you knew but didn't, and things you never thought you wanted to know, but do. Now, with "TMSIDK," he has a new way of doing just that. This new show is still journalism, still factual -- but disguised in the most entertaining, unexpected, and occasionally ridiculous conversation you're likely to hear. Audience contestants come on stage and try to wow a panel of experts with a fascinating fact, a historical wrinkle, a new line of research -- anything, really, as long as it's interesting, useful and true (or at least true-ish). The panel -- an ever-changing mix of comedians, brainiacs, and other high achievers -- poke and prod the contestants, and ultimately choose a winner. And there's a real-time, human fact-checker on hand to filter out the bull. This debut episode features Barnard College president Debora Spar, New York Public Library president Tony Marx, and comedian Andy Zaltzman; Jody Avirgan from FiveThirtyEight handles the fact-checking. You can subscribe now on iTunes. And don't worry, Freakonomics Radio isn't going anywhere -- this is just a special bonus episode of Dubner's new side gig.

item.title: 266. Trust Me
item.itunes:title: Trust Me
item.description: Societies where people trust one another are healthier and wealthier. In the U.S. (and the U.K. and elsewhere), social trust has been falling for decades -- in part because our populations are more diverse. What can we do to fix it?

item.title: 11. How Much Does the President Really Matter? (Rebroadcast )
item.itunes:title: How Much Does the President Really Matter? (Rebroadcast )
item.description: The U.S. president is often called the "leader of free world." But if you ask an economist or a Constitutional scholar how much the occupant of the Oval Office matters, they won't say much. We look at what the data have to say about measuring leadership, and its impact on the economy and the country.

item.title: 265. The White House Gets Into the Nudge Business
item.itunes:title: The White House Gets Into the Nudge Business
item.description: A tiny behavioral-sciences startup is trying to improve the way federal agencies do their work. Considering the size (and habits) of most federal agencies, this isn't so simple. But after a series of early victories -- and a helpful executive order from President Obama -- they are well on their way.

item.title: 264. In Praise of Incrementalism
item.itunes:title: In Praise of Incrementalism
item.description: What do Renaissance painting, civil-rights movements, and Olympic cycling have in common? In each case, huge breakthroughs came from taking tiny steps. In a world where everyone is looking for the next moonshot, we shouldn't ignore the power of incrementalism.

One recent MRI study sheds some light, finding that a certain kind of storytelling stimulates enormous activity across broad swaths of the brain. The takeaway is obvious: you should be listening to even more podcasts.

item.title: 261. Why Are We Still Using Cash?
item.itunes:title: Why Are We Still Using Cash?
item.description: It facilitates crime, bribery, and tax evasion -- and yet some governments (including ours) are printing more cash than ever. Other countries, meanwhile, are ditching cash entirely. And if Star Trek is right, we won't have money of any sort in the 24th century.

item.title: 260. Has the U.S. Presidency Become a Dictatorship?
item.itunes:title: Has the U.S. Presidency Become a Dictatorship?
item.description: Sure, we all pay lip service to the Madisonian system of checks and balances. But as one legal scholar argues, presidents have been running roughshod over the system for decades. The result? An accumulation of power that's turned the presidency into a position the founders wouldn't have recognized.

item.title: 257. The Future (Probably) Isn’t as Scary as You Think
item.itunes:title: The Future (Probably) Isn’t as Scary as You Think
item.description: Internet pioneer Kevin Kelly tries to predict the future by identifying what's truly inevitable. How worried should we be? Yes, robots will probably take your job -- but the future will still be pretty great.

item.title: 11. How Much Does the President Really Matter? (Rebroadcast)
item.itunes:title: How Much Does the President Really Matter? (Rebroadcast)

But if you ask an economist or a Constitutional scholar how much the occupant of the Oval Office matters, they won't say much. We look at what the data have to say about measuring leadership, and its impact on the economy and the country.

item.title: 248. How to Be Tim Ferriss
item.itunes:title: How to Be Tim Ferriss
item.description: Our Self-Improvement Month concludes with a man whose entire life and career are one big pile of self-improvement. Nutrition? Check. Bizarre physical activities? Check. Working less and earning more? Check. Tim Ferriss, creator of the Four-Hour universe, may at first glance look like a charlatan, but it seems more likely that he's a wizard -- and the kind of self-improvement ally we all want on our side.

item.description: Games are as old as civilization itself, and some people think they have huge social value regardless of whether you win or lose. Tom Whipple is not one of those people. That's why he consulted an army of preposterously overqualified experts to find the secret to winning any game.

item.description: The psychologist Angela Duckworth argues that a person's level of stick-to-itiveness is directly related to their level of success. No big surprise there. But grit, she says, isn't something you're born with -- it can be learned. Here's how.

item.title: 245. Being Malcolm Gladwell
item.itunes:title: Being Malcolm Gladwell
item.description: "Books are a pain in the ass," says Gladwell, who has written some of the most popular, influential, and beloved non-fiction books in recent history. In this wide-ranging and candid conversation, he describes other pains in the ass -- as well as his passions, his limits, and why he'll never take up golf.

item.title: 244. How to Become Great at Just About Anything
